contentrichtext.text: An '''X-ray interferometer''' is analogous to a [[neutron interferometer]]. It has been suggested that it may offer the very highest spatial resolution in [[astronomy]], though the technology is unproven as of 2008. <ref Name="Cash">{{cite web | last =Cash | first = Webster | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =X-ray Interferometry | work = | publisher =Center for Astrophysics and Space Astronomy; University of Colorado, Boulder, CO 80309-0389 | date = | url =http://casa.colorado.edu/~wcash/interf/Interfere.htm | format =web | doi = | accessdate = 2008-05-28 }}</ref> One technique is [[triple Laue interferometry]] (LLL interferometry).<ref>http://www.aps.anl.gov/Science/Reports/1999/fezzaak1.pdf</ref> ==See also== *[[High energy X-rays]] ==References== {{reflist}} *[http://e1.physik.uni-dortmund.de/xtm/ X-Ray and Neutron Interferometry] Author: Ulrich Bonse at uni-dortmund.de, 10 February 2005 [[Category:Interferometers]] {{tech-stub}}
